newsitem.title: CANADA: Coalition urges swift passage of Canadian MMT ban.
newsitem.headline: Coalition urges swift passage of Canadian MMT ban.

text.p: An unlikely coalition of carmakers, environmentalists and health groups urged the Canadian government on Wednesday to pass a bill swiftly to ban the gasoline additive MMT in Canada.
The contentious bill has pitted carmakers against the oil industry, a U.S. manufacturer against the Canadian government, with environmental and health lobbyists also joining the fray.

The government has put the bill high on its agenda, despite complaints from the manufacturer of MMT, Richmond, Va.-based Ethyl Corp., that studies about its ill effects are inconclusive or ill-founded.
MMT, methylcyclopentadienyl manganese tricarbonyl, boosts octane while cutting emissions of carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxide. But the groups advocate using other octane enhancers.

The environmentalists backed claims by the Big Three as well as international automakers that MMT gums up auto emission diagnostic systems and charged that manganese is a potential neurotoxin that might hurt brain development.

"Strong action is needed, not only to protect the diagnostic systems on board our automobiles, but to protect those diagnostic systems found in a more important piece of equipment, the human brain," Elizabeth May, executive director of the Sierra Club of Canada, told a news conference.
Canadian Automobile Association President Brian Hunt said MMT has been shown to hurt catalytic converters.
"Manganese from MMT coats the surfaces of the catalyst, reducing its ability to remove pollutants from exhaust passing through," Hunt said.

He added that MMT coats oxygen sensors that send vital information to a car's on-board computer, and, if the wrong oxygen readings are sent, the wrong mixture of air and fuel will be used, consuming more fuel and spewing more emissions.
The government bill to ban the import and inter-provincial trade of MMT was first introduced in May 1995, but it became overshadowed by the turmoil over whether Quebec should leave Canada.
The office of Herb Gray, who runs the government's legislative programme in the House of Commons, Parliament's lower chamber, said the bill was now fourth on the list of priorities.
"We're hoping we'll get to it next week," Gray's spokesman Dan Rogers said.

The situation is complicated by Ethyl Corp.'s announcement on Sept. 10 that it intended to submit a claim under the North American Free Trade Agreement for US$200 million against the Canadian government for damages to its Ethyl Canada subsidiary because of the legislation.
Ethyl has quoted the government department Health Canada as saying that the amount of manganese entering the environment is so tiny that it does constitute a health risk.
Sierra Club's May said it was important for the public not to view this as a clash merely between the oil and auto industries.

"They've been hearing about it as if it was entirely a conflict between the gas guys and the car guys, and it's time to make sure people understand that there's a health and environment risk that C-29 (this bill) will remove," she said.
Opposition parties have argued that it makes little sense to ban MMT shortly after the United States lifted its own ban.
